unnormalised: The BSE Sensex witnessed a volatile trading session today, closing at 76,490.08, a marginal increase of 0.05% after intra-day fluctuations. Nifty 50 mirrored the trend, settling at 23,264.85, reflecting cautious optimism amidst global uncertainties. Trading volumes remained moderate, with approximately Rs. 60,000 crore changing hands across major exchanges.
normalised: The B-S-E Sensex witnessed a volatile trading session today, closing at seventy six thousand four hundred and ninety point zero eight, a marginal increase of zero point zero five percent after intra-day fluctuations. Nifty fifty mirrored the trend, settling at twenty three thousand two hundred and sixty four point eight five, reflecting cautious optimism amidst global uncertainties. Trading volumes remained moderate, with approximately rupees sixty thousand crore changing hands across major exchanges.

unnormalised: Analysts attribute the subdued market activity to investors awaiting the release of key macroeconomic data scheduled for later this week. Inflation figures and industrial output numbers are expected to provide further direction. Foreign Institutional Investors (FIIs) were net sellers, offloading shares worth Rs. 800 crore, while Domestic Institutional Investors (DIIs) provided some support, injecting approximately Rs. 500 crore into the market.
normalised: Analysts attribute the subdued market activity to investors awaiting the release of key macroeconomic data scheduled for later this week. Inflation figures and industrial output numbers are expected to provide further direction. Foreign Institutional Investors (F-I-I-s) were net sellers, offloading shares worth rupees eight hundred crore, while Domestic Institutional Investors (D-I-I-s) provided some support, injecting approximately rupees five hundred crore into the market.

unnormalised: Within the sectoral indices, banking and financial services experienced mixed performance. HDFC Bank shares traded marginally lower, closing at Rs. 1,550.50, while ICICI Bank saw a slight uptick, reaching Rs. 1,180. State Bank of India (SBI) maintained stability, closing at Rs. 840. The IT sector exhibited resilience, with Infosys and TCS posting gains of 1.2% and 0.8% respectively.
normalised: Within the sectoral indices, banking and financial services experienced mixed performance. H-D-F-C Bank shares traded marginally lower, closing at rupees one thousand five hundred and fifty point fifty, while I-C-I-C-I Bank saw a slight uptick, reaching rupees one thousand one hundred and eighty. State Bank of India (S-B-I) maintained stability, closing at rupees eight hundred and forty. The I-T sector exhibited resilience, with Infosys and T-C-S posting gains of one point two percent and zero point eight percent respectively.

unnormalised: Market participants are closely monitoring developments in the global arena, including geopolitical tensions and monetary policy decisions by major central banks. The potential impact of monsoon progress on agricultural output also remains a key consideration. Experts advise investors to adopt a cautious approach, focusing on fundamentally strong companies and avoiding excessive leverage.
normalised: Market participants are closely monitoring developments in the global arena, including geopolitical tensions and monetary policy decisions by major central banks. The potential impact of monsoon progress on agricultural output also remains a key consideration. Experts advise investors to adopt a cautious approach, focusing on fundamentally strong companies and avoiding excessive leverage.

unnormalised: Going forward, the market is expected to remain range-bound in the near term, with potential for volatility depending on news flow. The next trading session will likely be influenced by overnight developments in international markets and early cues from Asian indices. Investors are advised to consult with financial advisors before making any investment decisions.
